questions.solution: Ans. D) Attached to pelvic brim

Contact monitoring must be done for a period of 21 days from day of contact.
It is caused by an enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding monkey pox is false?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Requires BSL-4 facilities for isolation

questions.text: Which of the following represents the origin of craniopharyngioma?

Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. IgG2 deficiency causes recurrent sinopulmonary infections specifically caused by encapsulated bacteria. 
  2. Positive hair perforation test is seen in Trichophyton mentagrophytes.
  3. Antibody detection in stool samples is the best diagnostic approach for confirming rotavirus infection
  4. Thayer Martin agar is the selective medium of choice for isolating Neisseria gonorrhoeae
Which of the following is connected to the structure marked as A in the image below?

Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Listeria monocytogenes uniquely utilizes actin filaments for intracellular movement
  2. XDR-TB is managed under BSL-3 conditions
  3. Urine lipoarabinomannan (LAM) assay is used for the diagnosis of tuberculosis and leprosy. 
  4. E.coli shows acid slant/acid butt with gas production on TSI agar
A 20-year-old farmer presents with firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules on the hairs of the scalp. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Piedraia hortae 

 

  • The patient is a farmer with black, gritty, hard nodules firmly attached to scalp hairs.
  • This is classic for Black piedra, a superficial fungal infection.
  • Causative organism: Piedraia hortae, a dematiaceous (dark-pigmented) fungus.
  • The nodules are fungal concretions tightly cemented around the hair shaft.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichosporon:

 

  • Causes White piedra.
  • Presents with soft, white to light-brown nodules loosely attached to hair shafts (beard, mustache, axilla, groin).

 

Option C. Hortaea werneckii:

 

  • Causes Tinea nigra, a superficial infection of the skin.
  • Appears as brown to black macules on palms/soles, not nodules on hair.

 

Option D. Aspergillus niger: Can colonize ear canal and cause otomycosis, not Piedra.

choices.text: Epinephrine may be used in refractory cases

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with tingling of lips and mouth, nausea, and flushing. He gives a history of eating a Mahi-Mahi fish about an hour back and that it had an unusual taste. He responds well to treatment with intravenous antihistamines. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Due to sea food allergy

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is supplied by the structure marked by red arrow?

choices.text: Detection of toxin in stool by PCR
Stool wet mount microscopy to visualize the organism
≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days

questions.text: A 58-year-old man on multiple antibiotics is suspected to have pseudomembranous colitis. The criteria for the diagnosis of the suspected condition include all, except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Stool wet mount microscopy to visualize the organism

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department unconscious after a motor vehicle accident. NCCT is shown here. A branch of which of the following arteries is most likely severed in this patient?

A 30-year-old female presents with chronic fatigue, weight loss, and hyperpigmentation. Her laboratory investigations are given below. Which is the source of the affected structure?

 

Na+ : 118 mEq/L

 

K+: 5.5 mEq/L

 

Cortisol: low

 

Aldosterone: low
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intermediate mesoderm

 

The patient has Addison’s disease (primary adrenal insufficiency) → characterized by:

 

  • Low cortisol (glucocorticoid deficiency → fatigue, weight loss).
  • Low aldosterone (mineralocorticoid deficiency → hyponatremia, hyperkalemia).
  • Hyperpigmentation (↑ACTH → ↑MSH activity due to lack of cortisol feedback).

 

The adrenal cortex is the affected structure here, and its embryological source is:

 

  • Adrenal cortex → Intermediate mesoderm (same origin as kidneys and gonads).

 

[Note: Adrenal medulla → Neural crest cells (gives rise to chromaffin cells).]

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paraxial mesoderm: Forms somites → axial skeleton, skeletal muscles, dermis.

 

Option C. Lateral plate mesoderm: Splits into parietal and visceral mesoderm → body wall, heart, blood vessels.

 

Option D. Neural crest cells: Give rise to adrenal medulla (chromaffin cells), not cortex.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl complains of low-grade fever and mild discomfort in her throat. On examination, a membrane is seen over the tonsil that can be removed easily. After removal of the membrane, an irregular ulcer is seen on the surface of the tonsil. What is the likely cause of Trench mouth?
Which of the following is an example of the same class of glands as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Meibomian glands

 

The histology image shows a sebaceous gland associated with a hair follicle:

 

  • These are holocrine glands, where the entire cell disintegrates to release its secretory product (sebum).
  • The secretion lubricates hair and skin.

 

Other examples of sebaceous/holocrine glands include:

 

  • Meibomian (tarsal) glands in the eyelids → secrete oily layer of tear film.
  • Fordyce spots (ectopic sebaceous glands)
  • Prepuce of Penis
  • Zeiss glands of eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mammary gland: Modified apocrine gland (secretion is apocrine + merocrine), not holocrine.

 

Option B. Ceruminous gland: Modified apocrine sweat gland in external auditory canal, produces earwax.

 

Option C. Sweat gland:

 

  • Eccrine sweat glands → merocrine type;
  • Apocrine sweat glands → apocrine type.
  • Not holocrine.

questions.text: What is the intermediate host for the organism shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No intermediate host

 

  • The image shows Ascaris lumbricoides, the large intestinal roundworm of humans.
  • Mode of transmission: ingestion of embryonated eggs from contaminated food, water, or soil (often raw vegetables).
  • Life cycle:
    • Eggs hatch in small intestine → larvae migrate via bloodstream to lungs → coughed up and swallowed → mature in small intestine.
  • Important point: Ascaris lumbricoides has a direct life cycle, meaning it does not require an intermediate host.
  • Humans are the only definitive host.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vegetables: They serve as a vehicle of transmission (contaminated with eggs), but not as an intermediate host.

 

Option B. Pig: Intermediate host for Taenia solium, not Ascaris.

 

Option C. Cattle: Intermediate host for Taenia saginata, not Ascaris.

choices.text: Enriched in the fingers and toes
Has unmyelinated nerve terminal that is surrounded by Schwann cells

questions.text: All of the following are true about Meissner corpuscles except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Best for static 2 point discrimination

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a history of urethral discharge for the last three days. A gram stain smear of the discharge is shown below. All of the following are true regarding the likely etiology except:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Catalase negative, oxidase positive

questions.text: Identify the branch of the structure marked ‘a’ in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Radial recurrent artery

 

The image shows a dissection of the forearm, with the structure marked ‘a’ being the radial artery.

 

  • The radial recurrent artery is an early branch of the radial artery.
  • It ascends proximally to anastomose with the radial collateral branch of the profunda brachii artery around the elbow joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior interosseous artery:

 

  • Branch of the common interosseous artery (from the ulnar artery).
  • Runs along the anterior surface of the interosseous membrane.

 

Option B. Anterior ulnar recurrent artery:

 

  • Branch of the ulnar artery.
  • Ascends to anastomose with the inferior ulnar collateral artery.

 

Option C. Posterior interosseous artery:

 

  • Branch of the common interosseous artery (from the ulnar artery).
  • Runs posteriorly through the interosseous membrane.

questions.text: A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. All of the following organisms can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus aureus

 

  • The image shows multiple noduloulcerative lesions along the lymphatic drainage of the leg → classic for sporotrichoid spread (also called lymphocutaneous spread).
  • Characterized by a chain of subcutaneous nodules/ulcers following lymphatics.
  • S. aureus usually causes localized abscesses, cellulitis, or furunculosis.
  • It spreads hematogenously or locally, but does not characteristically spread along lymphatic channels producing sporotrichoid lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Dimorphic fungus, causes Sporotrichosis, classically from rose thorns, sphagnum moss.

 

Option C. Nocardia asteroids: Can cause cutaneous nocardiosis with lymphocutaneous spread.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium marinum: Causes “swimming pool granuloma,” spreads along lymphatics.

choices.text: Mesencephalic nucleus - Proprioception from muscles of mastication
Principal sensory nucleus - Touch from face
Special visceral efferent - Muscles of mastication

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair of function with trigeminal nucleus:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spinal nucleus - Touch from neck

 

  • Function: Pain and temperature sensation from face (not touch from neck). 
  • Extends down to C2–C3 spinal cord levels.

 

The trigeminal sensory nuclei extend through the brainstem and subserve different modalities:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.Mesencephalic nucleus: Function: Proprioception (from muscles of mastication, TMJ, teeth, and periodontal ligaments).

 

Option B. Principal (chief) sensory nucleus: Function: Fine touch, vibration, and pressure from the face.

 

Option D. Special visceral efferent-Muscles of mastication: Function: Motor innervation to muscles of mastication (masseter, temporalis, medial & lateral pterygoid) and a few others (tensor tympani, tensor veli palatini, mylohyoid, anterior belly of digastric).

questions.text: The epithelium lining of the following organ is:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Columnar epithelium with brush border

questions.text: Match the following conditions with their causative agents:
questions.solution: Ans. B) I-D, II-A, III-B, IV-C

questions.text:
Galactomannan in serum is seen in: 

 

  1. Invasive aspergillosis
  2. Systemic candidiasis
  3. Mucormycosis
  4. Cryptococcosis

A 4-year-old child presents with an upper limb deformity as given in the image below. Examination shows a wide split and fixed second heart sound through all phases of respiration. Identify the heart disease likely to be present in this child:
A petechial rash is associated with all the following except?

choices.text: Bacteria that form biofilms are usually metabolically more active

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about biofilms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bacteria that form biofilms are usually metabolically more active

 

  • Biofilms are structured communities of bacteria enclosed in a self-produced glycocalyx (extracellular polysaccharide matrix) and attached to surfaces (prosthetic devices, catheters, teeth, mucosa, etc).

 

Within biofilms:

 

  • Bacteria are usually in a low metabolic state → making them more resistant to antibiotics and host defenses.
  • Biofilms use quorum sensing (cell-to-cell signaling via autoinducers) to coordinate growth, virulence, and detachment.
  • They are responsible for chronic and prosthetic infections (eg, Staphylococcus epidermidis in prosthetic valves/catheters, Pseudomonas in CF lungs, dental plaque).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Responsible for prosthetic infections: True.

 

  • Biofilms are notorious in prosthetic device–related infections (eg, prosthetic heart valves, joint replacements, central venous catheters, urinary catheters, intrauterine devices).
  • Within biofilms, bacteria are resistant to antibiotics and immune responses, leading to chronic, relapsing infections that often require removal of the device.
  • Example organisms:
    • Staphylococcus epidermidis → prosthetic valve endocarditis.
    • Pseudomonas aeruginosa → biofilms in cystic fibrosis lungs and on catheters.

 

Option C. Glycocalyx enclosed bacteria: True.

 

  • Biofilm bacteria are embedded in a self-produced extracellular polymeric substance (EPS), often called glycocalyx.
  • This glycocalyx:
    • Protects bacteria from antibiotics, antibodies, and phagocytosis.
    • Provides structural stability and nutrient exchange.
  • Classic example: Streptococcus mutans in dental plaque, producing a glycocalyx from sucrose.

 

Option D. Associated with quorum sensing: True.

 

  • Quorum sensing is the mechanism bacteria use to “talk” to each other via autoinducers (chemical signals).
  • Once a threshold bacterial density is reached, coordinated gene expression occurs → promoting biofilm formation, virulence factor production, and dispersal.
  • Examples:
    • Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses quorum sensing to regulate biofilm thickness and toxin production.
    • Vibrio fischeri uses quorum sensing for bioluminescence (classic model system).

choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop assay for ETEC
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.text: Which of the following is a xenodiagnostic method?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman has a right-sided ovarian mass found incidentally on transvaginal ultrasound.  Surgery is planned to remove the right ovary, including the mass. To avoid excessive bleeding during the oophorectomy, the surgeon should ligate which of the following structures?

A patient presented with a prolonged fever of unknown origin (PUO), raising suspicion of brucellosis. To confirm the diagnosis, various dilutions of the patient's serum sample are prepared for a standard agglutination test. The outcome is as follows: Agglutination is observed at serum dilutions of 1:20 and 1:40, while no agglutination occurs at dilutions of 1:80 and 1:160. What factor is accountable for the lack of agglutination in the last two dilutions?
A 6-year-old child falls from his bicycle and injures his hand. On X-ray, a fracture of the first metacarpal bone is noticed. Where is the epiphysis of the affected bone?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) At the base

 

The first metacarpal (thumb metacarpal) is unique compared to the other metacarpals:

 

  • For 2nd–5th metacarpals → the epiphysis is located at the head (distal end).
  • For the 1st metacarpal (thumb) → the epiphysis is located at the base (proximal end).

 

This difference is clinically important when evaluating growth plate injuries in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. At the neck: Epiphysis is never located at the neck region.

 

Option C. At the head: True for 2nd–5th metacarpals, but not for the 1st metacarpal.

 

Option D. In the shaft: The shaft contains the diaphysis, not the epiphysis.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for the treatment the disease, caused by the organism whose life cycle is shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV Penicillin G

 

  • The diagram (CDC) shows the life cycle of Capillaria hepatica, a nematode parasite.
  • Key features:
    • Adult worms live in the liver of rodents or humans.
    • Eggs are released after host death (decomposition or predation).
    • Transmission occurs via ingestion of embryonated eggs.
  • Human disease: Hepatic capillariasis, which presents with hepatomegaly, fever, eosinophilia, and liver dysfunction.
  • Treatment of choice:
    • IV Penicillin G is recommended as the mainstay treatment.
    • In some cases, adjunctive corticosteroids may be added to control inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oral Amoxicillin: Broad-spectrum antibiotic, used for respiratory tract infections but not effective against Capillaria hepatica.

 

Option C. Oral Azithromycin: Macrolide, mainly for bacterial respiratory or STI infections; no role here.

 

Option D. Oral Ampicillin: Beta-lactam antibiotic, used in Listeriosis & Enterococcal infection, not effective for parasitic nematodes.

questions.text:
Arrange right lung hilar structures from superior to inferior:

 

  1. Superior lobar bronchus
  2. Pulmonary artery
  3. Principal bronchus
  4. Inferior pulmonary vein

Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. The fornix contains both association fibers and commissural fibers
  2. Neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall lies in between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis
  3. There are two dorsal interossei at the middle finger
  4. Left superior intercostal vein drains into the azygos vein
Which of the following viruses exhibits genetic re-assortment similar to that of influenza virus?
A 30-year-old man who frequently travels barefoot is suspected to have acquired a parasitic infection via skin penetration. Any of the following parasites may be implicated in this case except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enterobius vermicularis

 

  • The patient has infection acquired via skin penetration (walking barefoot).
  • Parasites that penetrate intact skin include:
    • Necator americanus / Ancylostoma duodenale → hookworms, penetrate skin → cause “ground itch,” then migrate to lungs → intestine.
    • Strongyloides stercoralis → filariform larvae penetrate skin → migrate to lungs and intestine.
    • Schistosoma species (eg, S. haematobium) → cercariae penetrate skin while swimming in contaminated freshwater.
  • Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) infection is acquired by ingestion of embryonated eggs, not by skin penetration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Necator americanus: Hookworm, acquired by skin penetration, causes iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option C. Strongyloides stercoralis: Larvae penetrate skin, cause autoinfection, hyperinfection in immunocompromised.

 

Option D. Schistosoma haematobium: Cercariae penetrate skin in freshwater, later cause urinary schistosomiasis (hematuria, bladder cancer).

questions.text: Identify the tissue from the histology appearance:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymus

 

The tissue shown in the image is thymus. The characteristic histological feature seen here is the Hassall's corpuscle (concentric keratinized epithelial reticular cells), which is found only in the medulla of the thymus. They are eosinophilic and may show keratinization in older individuals. These structures are unique to the thymus and play a role in T cell development and maturation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spleen: Spleen does not have Hassall’s corpuscles. It contains White Pulp and Red pulp.

 

Option C. Prostate: Prostate contains prostatic glands and Corpora amylacea

 

Option D. Urinary bladder: Urinary bladder shows transitional epithelium. Beneath this is a lamina propria of connective tissue, followed by a thick muscularis layer (detrusor muscle) composed of interlacing smooth muscle bundles.

questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis with a history of fever for 4 days and erythematous rashes on the chest. There was no history of travel and tick bite. His CSF findings showed increased protein, normal glucose, mild lymphocytosis and few RBCs. Which of the following is the most likely organism to cause this clinical picture?

A teenager presents with fever, malaise, skin rash and hepatomegaly. He is diagnosed with a rickettsial infection and the vector implicated in the disease is shown below. The vector can transmit which of the following diseases?
Identify the organism in the given image showing KOH and LPCB culture morphology:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rhizopus

 

  • The image shows fungal morphology under KOH mount and Lactophenol Cotton Blue (LPCB) stain.
  • Key features visible:
    • Broad, aseptate hyphae (typical of Zygomycetes).
    • Sporangium (round, black structure containing spores).
    • Rhizoids (root-like structures anchoring the hyphae).
  • Rhizopus is differentiated from Mucor by the presence of well-developed rhizoids opposite the sporangiophores.
  • These features confirm the organism as Rhizopus, a common cause of mucormycosis (zygomycosis), especially in diabetics with ketoacidosis and immunocompromised patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus: Shows acute-angle, septate hyphae and conidial heads, not sporangia with rhizoids.

 

Option B. Mucor: Also has broad, aseptate hyphae and sporangia, but lacks rhizoids (key differentiator from Rhizopus).

 

Option D. Blastomyces: 

 

  • A dimorphic fungus that exists as yeast in tissue (broad-based budding) and mold in environment.
  • Does not produce sporangia or rhizoids.

questions.text: Which structure passes through the marked opening
The man present with a case of cervical rib has tingling sensation and paresthesia on the medial side of arm. Which of the following marked structure is most likely affected?
Which of the following sites is used for the influenza virus vaccine production?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Allantoic cavity

 

  • Influenza virus is traditionally grown in embryonated chicken eggs for vaccine production.
  • The allantoic cavity is the preferred site for influenza virus inoculation because:
    • It provides a large fluid-filled space.
    • Virus replicates well and accumulates in the allantoic fluid.
    • Easy to harvest virus in large amounts for vaccine preparation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chorioallantoic membrane (CAM):

 

  • Used for growth of vaccinia virus, herpes simplex virus, variola virus (smallpox).
  • Produces visible pocks/lesions on the membrane.

 

Option B. Suckling mice:

 

  • Used for isolation of certain arboviruses, rabies virus, and coxsackie viruses.
  • Not used for influenza vaccine production.

 

Option C. Primary cell line: Human embryonic kidney (HEK) cells is an example, used in vaccine production and virus cultivation.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room after she sustained a supracondylar fracture of the humerus with injury to the structure marked as 'A' in the given image. Which of the following is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abduction of thumb

 

The marked structure 'A' in the image is the median nerve. Injury to the median nerve at the level of the supracondylar humerus fracture most commonly affects abduction of the thumb (thenar muscle: abductor pollicis brevis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adduction of thumb: Done by adductor pollicis (ulnar nerve).

 

Option C. Flexion of little finger: Flexor digiti minimi (ulnar nerve).

 

Option D. Abduction of little finger: Abductor digiti minimi (ulnar nerve).

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

 

  1. Topical mupirocin is the recommended treatment for the nasal decolonization of MRSA

  2. The Mw vaccine is extracted from Mycobacterium indicus pranii, used in the immunotherapy of malaria.

  3. The ratio of T cells to B cells in a healthy adult is approximately 1:3

  4. Ratio of CD4 to CD8 T-cells is 2: 1.

A sputum sample shows gram-positive cocci on microscopy. The organism is catalase-negative and shows partial hemolysis on blood agar. Which of the following tests can be performed to differentiate the organisms? 

 

  1. Optochin sensitivity
  2. Bacitracin sensitivity
  3. Growth in 6.5% NaCl
  4. Bile solubility
  5. Novobiocin sensitivity
Given is a model of embryological development of the heart. Which structure develops from the area marked with red arrow?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right ventricle

 

The area marked by the red arrow in this embryological heart development diagram represents the bulbus cordis region. The bulbus cordis, marked by the red arrow, is a vital embryonic region in heart development. It ultimately forms the outflow tract and most of the right ventricle in the adult heart. Abnormal development of this region can result in congenital heart defects involving the right ventricle or outflow tracts.

 

Right ventricle develops primarily from the proximal part of the bulbus cordis. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorta: Aorta and pulmonary artery develop from the truncus arteriosus. 

 

Option B. Left Ventricle: LV develops from the primitive ventricle which mainly becomes the left ventricle, contributing its muscular wall and cavity.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old female patient presents with generalised seizures. MRI is shown below.  All of the following should be done regarding management in this case? 

 

 

  1. USG orbit 
  2. Mantoux test
  3. Start Anti-seizure medication 
  4. Dexamethasone 
  5. Albendazole

A 35-year-old man presents with painful lesions in the oral mucosa and enlarged lymph nodes. The microscopy of the patient's lymph node exudate shows the following appearance. What is the most likely causative agent?
During the clinical examination of the nervous system, which of the following nerves can be tested by touching the highlighted structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IX

 

The highlighted structure in the image is the uvula (part of the soft palate).

 

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) provides sensory innervation (general sensation) to the posterior one-third of the tongue, pharynx, and soft palate (including uvula).
  • During clinical examination, touching the uvula or posterior pharyngeal wall elicits the gag reflex → sensory limb by CN IX, motor limb by CN X.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. X (Vagus nerve):

 

  • Provides motor innervation to most muscles of the pharynx and soft palate (except tensor veli palatini).
  • Responsible for the motor limb of the gag reflex and movement of uvula (deviation test).

 

Option C. XI (Accessory nerve):

 

  • Supplies sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
  • Not involved in gag reflex or sensation of uvula. Tested by Shrugging of Shoulder against resistance. 

 

Option D. XII (Hypoglossal nerve):

 

  • Supplies intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue (except palatoglossus).
  • Tested by tongue protrusion, not by touching uvula.

questions.text: Identify the tributaries of the vessel marked in the image except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left 5th posterior intercostal vein

 

The vessel marked in the image is the azygos vein. The left 5th posterior intercostal vein (D) is a tributary of the hemiazygos or accessory hemiazygos vein, not the azygos vein.

 

Azygos vein tributaries are:

 

  • Right ascending lumbar vein[A]
  • Right subcostal vein[B]
  • Right posterior intercostal veins[C] (e.g., right 5th)

questions.text: Which of the following is the cellular receptor for the virus shown in the image below?
Absent patellar reflex could be a result of injury to which of the following nerve?

A 32-year-old man comes to the OPD for a follow-up appointment. The patient recently returned from a 10-day trip to Thailand. On the fifth day of his trip, he developed malaise, anorexia, and abdominal cramps, quickly followed by watery diarrhea. The patient had 5 or 6 stools daily but no fever. The patient felt better after 2 days and has had no additional symptoms since.  Which of the following factors was most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's gastrointestinal symptoms?

Vesicular rash is seen in which of the following?

 

  1. Hand, foot, and mouth disease
  2. Dengue
  3. Zika fever
  4. Roseola infantum
  5. Syphilis

Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Phase contrast microscopy is the technique used to study motility in live bacteria. 
  2. Interferon-beta (IFN-β) is a type I interferon, which is predominantly secreted in response to viral infections. 
  3. Alveolar echinococcosis can mimic HCC on imaging.
  4. Protein A binds the Fc portion of lgG
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

1. Kanagawa phenomenon is seen with V. vulnificus and V. parahaemolyticus: Incorrect. Kanagawa phenomenon (beta-hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar) is seen only with pathogenic strains of Vibrio parahaemolyticus, not with V. vulnificus.

 

2. TLR3 and AXL receptors are associated with Nipah virus: Incorrect.

 

  • TLR3 and AXL are linked with Zika virus entry and recognition, not Nipah.
  • Nipah virus entry is mediated by Ephrin-B2 and Ephrin-B3 receptors.

 

3. Dusting powder can be sterilised by autoclave: Incorrect. Powders are sterilized by dry heat (hot air oven, 160°C for 1 hour), not by autoclave (moist heat), which would cause clumping.

 

4. Schistosomes are monoecious: Incorrect.

 

  • Schistosomes are the only dioecious trematodes (male and female worms separate).
  • Most other trematodes are monoecious.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man with fever and joint pain is found to have a disease caused by an enveloped virus containing partially double-stranded circular DNA. An enzyme packed in its virion has RNA-dependent DNA-polymerase activity. This patient is most likely infected with which of the following viruses?
A farmer presents with a swollen foot and multiple sinuses. MRI is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Which of the following structures pass through the marked green foramen? 

 

 

  1. Inferior petrosal sinus
  2. Spinal accessory nerve
  3. Vagus nerve
  4. Hypoglossal nerve
  5. Middle meningeal branch of the occipital artery
  6. Deep petrosal nerve

Vaccination against which of the following is recommended in the elderly? 

  1. Varicella zoster virus
  2. COVID-19
  3. Measles
  4. Pneumococcal meningitis
  5. HPV
  6. Td
Identify the structure based on the histological features of the specimen obtained after TAH + BSO

choices.text: Dermis has dense irregular connective tissue
Fibrocartilage, bones, tendons have collagen type I
Hyaline cartilage has perichondrium with 2-4 chondrocytes in each lacuna
Fibres from Inferior olivary nucleus directly reach the purkinje cells in cerebellum, which constitute the largest neurons in human brain.

questions.text: All of the following are true except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Fibres from Inferior olivary nucleus directly reach the purine cells in cerebellum, which constitute the largest neurons in human brain

questions.text: What is the nature of the causative virus of pharyngoconjunctival fever?
Fibers from the structure marked in blue, terminate at which of the following?
Identify the organism from the head end as shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D. latum

 

  • The image shows the head end (scolex) of a tapeworm.
  • Key identifying feature:
    • Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm) has a scolex with two elongated sucking grooves (bothria) instead of suckers or hooks.
    • This distinguishes it from other cestodes.
  • Clinical association:
    • Causes diphyllobothriasis, acquired from eating raw/undercooked freshwater fish.
    • Can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency → megaloblastic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hymenolepis nana (Dwarf tapeworm):

 

  • Scolex has four suckers + rostellum with hooks.
  • Smallest tapeworm infecting humans.

 

 

Option B. Taenia solium (Pork tapeworm): Scolex has four suckers + rostellum armed with hooks (“armed tapeworm”).

 

 

Option C. Echinococcus granulosus:

 

  • Scolex has four suckers + double row of hooks.
  • Causes hydatid cyst disease in humans.

 

 

Summary of heads and proglottids of various cystodes:-

questions.text: A young man is rushed to the emergency department after suffering a stab wound over the chest wall. The entry wound is present on the left side in the mid-axillary line. The lung is likely to be injured if the entry wound is above which level?

A 29-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with new-onset generalized tonic-clonic seizures. She has a history of HIV and has not been taking her medications consistently. According to her family, she has been sleepy and weak for the past 2 weeks. MRI is shown. Which of the following would be effective against the pathogen most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
All of the following muscles have dual nerve supply except?
All of the following are features of the secondary stage of lymphogranuloma venereum except:

choices.text: Contralateral loss of pain & temperature in trunk and limbs
Contralateral loss of position and vibration sense
Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from face
Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of palate

questions.text: MRI of 60-year-old female reveals a defect in the territory served by the artery marked in given MRA. Which of the following features is not a component of the syndrome related to the vessel indicated by the yellow arrows?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Contralateral loss of position and vibration sense

questions.text: A 6-hour-old boy is evaluated in the newborn nursery due to temperature instability, grunting, and lethargy. The patient was born at full term to a 21-year-old woman who came to the emergency department in active labor with ruptured membranes; she had not received adequate prenatal care. On physical examination, the boy is hypothermic, tachycardic, and tachypneic, and he has mottled skin. Cultures on blood agar grow bacterial colonies with a narrow zone of clear hemolysis. When these bacteria are grown in the presence of Staphylococcus aureus, the zone of hemolysis is enhanced around the staphylococcal colonies. Which of the following is the most likely pathogen infecting this patient?

A 55-year-old man with a history of smoking and hypertension presents to the clinic with difficulty swallowing and hoarseness. On examination, he has a decreased gag reflex and asymmetry of the soft palate with uvula deviating to the left upon phonation. These findings suggest a lesion in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nucleus Ambiguus

 

The nucleus ambiguus is located in the medulla and contains branchial motor (special visceral efferent) fibers.

 

  • It supplies motor innervation via cranial nerves IX, X, and cranial part of XI to:
    • Muscles of pharynx (except stylopharyngeus by CN IX, palatoglossus by CN X).
    • Muscles of soft palate (except tensor veli palatini by CN V3).
    • Muscles of larynx.

 

Clinical findings in this patient:

 

  • Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) → pharyngeal muscle paralysis.
  • Hoarseness → laryngeal muscle paralysis (CN X).
  • Decreased gag reflex → loss of motor limb (CN X via nucleus ambiguus).
  • Uvula deviation to the left → lesion on the right nucleus ambiguus or right vagus nerve, since the uvula deviates away from the lesion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoglossal nucleus:

 

  • Supplies tongue muscles.
  • Lesion → tongue atrophy & deviation (not uvula).

 

Option B. Nucleus solitarius:

 

  • Sensory nucleus (visceral afferents).
  • Involved in taste (CN VII, IX, X) and visceral sensation.

 

Option D. Dorsal motor nucleus of vagus:

 

  • Parasympathetic nucleus of CN X.
  • Controls thoracic/abdominal viscera, not palate or laryngeal muscles.

choices.text: Carriers of this disease can be treated with Rifampicin
It can lead to adrenal hemorrhage
Terminal complement deficiency increases the risk of this disease
Azithromycin is the drug of choice

questions.text: A 21-year-old female complains of fever, headache and vomiting from the past 3 days. She has been living in the army recruitment camp for the last three weeks. On examination, she has neck stiffness and petechial rash was noted over the trunk and extremities. Which of the following is false about the disease she's likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Azithromycin is the drug of choice

 

Crowded living (camp), acute fever, neck stiffness, petechial rash → classic meningococcal meningitis/septicemia due to Neisseria meningitidis.

 

First-line therapy is IV third-generation cephalosporin (ceftriaxone or cefotaxime). High-dose penicillin G is an alternative if susceptibility confirmed. Azithromycin is not the drug of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carriers of this disease can be treated with Rifampicin: Rifampin eradicates nasopharyngeal carriage (chemoprophylaxis for close contacts; alternatives: ciprofloxacin, ceftriaxone).

 

Option B. It can lead to adrenal hemorrhage: Can cause Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome (adrenal hemorrhage, shock).

 

Option C. Azithromycin is the drug of choice: Terminal complement (C5–C9) deficiency markedly increases risk of recurrent N. meningitidis infections.

questions.text:
Sequential arrangement of secretomotor pathway to lacrimal gland:

 

  1. Pons
  2. Nerve of pterygoid canal
  3. Geniculate ganglion
  4. Nervus intermedius 
  5. Lacrimal nerve
  6. Greater petrosal nerve
  7. Pterygopalatine ganglion
  8. Zygomaticotemporal nerve

choices.text: It cannot be grown in sabouraud dextrose agar
Can be transmitted through soil in bat caves
It doesn’t cause person to person transmission.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient present with chronic fever.  Bone marrow examination of this patient is shown in the given image. Which of the following statement is false about the organism shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It cannot be grown in sabouraud dextrose agar

 

  • The image shows Histoplasma capsulatum inside macrophages (small intracellular yeasts with halo).

 

Clinical vignette: Patient with chronic fever, bone marrow involvement → consistent with disseminated histoplasmosis.

 

It cannot be grown in Sabouraud dextrose agar :- False.

 

  • Histoplasma capsulatum can be cultured on Sabouraud dextrose agar.
  • Shows dimorphic nature:
    • Mold form at 25°C (tuberculate macroconidia).
    • Yeast form at 37°C (in tissue, inside macrophages).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spores are infective form: True. Microconidia (spores) inhaled from environment → infective form.

 

Option C. Can be transmitted through soil in bat caves: True. Found in soil enriched with bird or bat droppings (eg, caves → “spelunker’s disease”).

 

Option D. It doesn’t cause person-to-person transmission: True.

  • Spread is only by inhalation of spores from environment.
  • No human-to-human transmission.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

 

1. Rapid crenation and degeneration of entire cell sheath → Enterovirus (A)

 

  • Enteroviruses cause rapid cell destruction with complete degeneration of the monolayer (“crenation”).

 

2. Large granular lumps resembling bunch of grapes → Adenovirus (B)

 

  • Adenovirus produces large intranuclear inclusions causing clumping of cells that resemble a bunch of grapes.

 

3. Diffuse rounding and ballooning of cell line → HSV (C)

 

  • Herpes Simplex Virus infection leads to ballooning degeneration, rounding of cells, and formation of multinucleated giant cells.

 

4. Cytoplasmic vacuolations → SV-40 (D)

 

  • Simian Virus-40 (polyomavirus) typically produces cytoplasmic vacuolation in infected cells (classic vacuolating CPE).

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy develops a severe headache, fever, and stiff neck after swimming in a poorly maintained freshwater lake. He rapidly progresses to seizures and altered mental status. CSF examination is shown below. What is the infective form of the organism?

Which of the following is not a branch of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery?

 

  1. Iliolumbar artery
  2. Lateral sacral artery
  3. Inferior gluteal artery
  4. Superior gluteal artery
  5. Superior vesical artery
  6. Obturator artery

A 17-year-old boy under remission for AML develops severe throat pain. He has lost his ability to swallow and has severe neck and chest pain. Upon admission, he has signs of sepsis and respiratory distress. Which is the organism most likely to be involved in this condition?
In which of the following chambers can one palpate a muscular ridge, which is the site of origin of pectinate muscles?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right atrium

 

The pectinate muscles are parallel ridges of myocardium.

 

  • In the right atrium, they are prominent in the anterior wall and especially in the auricle.
  • They originate from a muscular ridge called the crista terminalis, which separates the smooth posterior part of the atrium (sinus venarum) from the rough anterior part.
  • This ridge can be palpated and serves as the site of origin of the pectinate muscles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left atrium: Mostly smooth-walled, except for a few pectinate muscles in the left auricle, but no well-defined crista terminalis like in the right atrium.

 

Option C. Right ventricle: Contains trabeculae carneae (irregular muscular ridges)

 

Option D. Left ventricle: Also has trabeculae carneae, papillary muscles, and chordae tendineae, but no pectinate muscles.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is evaluated due to cough for 2 weeks. The patient has not received vaccinations. Temperature is 37.1° C (98.8° F), blood pressure is 98/66 mmHg, and respirations are 30/min. Oxygen saturation is 98%. On physical examination, when the patient coughs intermittently, his face turns red. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Leukocyte count is 22,000/mm (75% lymphocytes). The most effective pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition will directly interfere with which of the following cellular processes?

choices.text: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene
CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell
Commonest manifestation of CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea
UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to Foscarnet

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene

questions.text:
Food poisoning due to which of the following organisms is typically associated with 8-16 hours of incubation period?

 

  1. C. jejuni 
  2. Bacillus cereus - Emetic type
  3. Bacillus cereus - Diarrheal type
  4. Vibrio cholerae
  5. Clostridium perfringens
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 & 5

 

3. Bacillus cereus – Diarrheal type:


Incubation: 8–16 hours.


Due to ingestion of spores, followed by toxin formation in the intestine.
Causes watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps.

 

5. Clostridium perfringens:


Incubation: 8–16 hours.


Spores germinate in the intestine and produce enterotoxin, leading to watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps.

 

Other Statements:

 

Food poisoning incubation periods vary depending on the toxin versus infection mechanism.

 

1. Campylobacter jejuni: 


Incubation: 1–7 days (not hours).
Causes invasive diarrhea, abdominal pain, fever.

 

2. Bacillus cereus – Emetic type: 


Incubation: 1–6 hours.
Caused by preformed toxin (cereulide) in rice (“fried rice syndrome”).

 

4. Vibrio cholerae: 


Incubation: 24–72 hours.
Causes profuse “rice-water stools.”

 

Educational Objectives:

 

  • Short incubation (less than 6 hours): caused by preformed toxins, e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus cereus emetic type.
  • Intermediate incubation (8–16 hours): toxin produced inside the intestine, e.g., Bacillus cereus diarrheal type, Clostridium perfringens.
  • Long incubation (more than 24 hours): caused by invasive organisms, e.g., Salmonella, Campylobacter, Vibrio.

questions.text:
Identify the incorrect statements:

 

  1. Kanagawa phenomenon is seen with V.vulnificans and V.parahemolyticus
  2. TLR3 and AXL receptors are associated with Nipah virus. 
  3. Dusting powder can be sterilised by autoclave. 
  4. Schistosomes are monoecious
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

1. Kanagawa phenomenon is seen with V. vulnificus and V. parahaemolyticus: Incorrect. Kanagawa phenomenon (beta-hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar) is seen only with pathogenic strains of Vibrio parahaemolyticus, not with V. vulnificus.

 

 

2. TLR3 and AXL receptors are associated with Nipah virus: Incorrect.

  • TLR3 and AXL are linked with Zika virus entry and recognition, not Nipah.
  • Nipah virus entry is mediated by Ephrin-B2 and Ephrin-B3 receptors.

 

3. Dusting powder can be sterilised by autoclave: Incorrect. Powders are sterilized by dry heat (hot air oven, 160°C for 1 hour), not by autoclave (moist heat), which would cause clumping.

 

4. Schistosomes are monoecious: Incorrect.

 

  • Schistosomes are the only dioecious trematodes (male and female worms separate).
  • Most other trematodes are monoecious.

choices.text: It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal and maxillary bones.
Stem of lateral sulcus lies underneath.
Middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.
It corresponds to site of anterolateral fontanelle of fetal skull.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the marked structure:
questions.solution: Ans. A) It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal and maxillary bones.

questions.text: A man was brought to the hospital after he suffered a stab wound. CT-scan revealed an injury to the part of the artery that lies lateral to pectoralis minor muscle. Which of the following vessels is least likely to have its flow cut off completely?

Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Miyagawa corpuscles are found in K.granulomatosis
  2. S. sonnei shows late lactose fermentation
  3. B. Cepacia complex strains are intrinsically resistant to  Aminoglycosides and cephalosporins
  4. Cytomegalovirus is the leading cause of infection in renal transplant recipients during the first four months post-transplantation.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3, 4

 

2. S. sonnei shows late lactose fermentation: Correct.

 

  • Among Shigella, S. sonnei is a late lactose fermenter (others are typically non-lactose fermenters).

 

3. Burkholderia cepacia complex strains are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides and cephalosporins: Correct.

 

  • BCC exhibits intrinsic resistance to many agents, notably aminoglycosides and several β-lactams/cephalosporins.

 

4. Cytomegalovirus is the leading cause of infection in renal transplant recipients during the first four months: Correct.

 

  • CMV is the most common significant viral infection in the early post-transplant period (especially 1–4 months).

 

Incorrect Statement: 

 

1. Miyagawa corpuscles are found in K. granulomatosis: Incorrect.

 

  • Granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) due to Klebsiella granulomatis shows Donovan bodies (safety-pin intracellular organisms) in macrophages, not Miyagawa corpuscles.
  • “Miyagawa” inclusions are classically described with chlamydial inclusions, not donovanosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with right-sided hemiparesis and hemisensory loss of the leg and foot. He is unable to correctly identify objects and has significant personality changes. The occlusion of which of the following arteries could be responsible for these symptoms?

choices.text: Fruit bats are the natural host

questions.text: A 47-year-old pig farmer presented with fever, headaches, myalgia, and a sore throat. He later develops dizziness, altered consciousness, and seizures.  Identify the false statement regarding the condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No human to human transmission

 

  • The scenario describes Nipah virus infection:
    • Occupation: pig farmer (pig amplification host).
    • Clinical: fever, myalgia, sore throat → encephalitis with seizures, altered consciousness.

 

Epidemiology: outbreaks in South & Southeast Asia. No human to human transmission – False statement regarding Nipah virus.

 

  • Nipah virus can spread human-to-human, particularly via respiratory secretions and in healthcare settings.
    • Documented in outbreaks in Bangladesh and India

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Causative organism is a paramyxovirus: True. Nipah virus belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family, genus Henipavirus.

 

Option B. Pigs are the intermediate hosts: True. Fruit bats (Pteropus) are the natural reservoir, while pigs act as intermediate/amplifying hosts.

 

Option D. Fruit bats are the natural host: True. Pteropus fruit bats are the reservoir hosts, shedding virus in saliva, urine, and excreta.

Arrange in sequence the structures involved in the direct pathway:

 

1. Striatum

2. Globus pallidus

3. Substantia nigra

4. Thalamus

5. Cortex

6. Subthalamic nucleus

A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of abdominal pain and diarrhea. He reports that his stools are streaked with blood and mucus. He returned from a vacation in Kerala 3 weeks ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows hyperactive bowel sounds. A photomicrograph of a trichrome-stained wet mount of a stool specimen is shown. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

Identify the correct statements 

 

  1. Plantar arterial arch lies between the second & third layer of sole
  2. At the age of 3 years, handedness can be seen. 
  3. Liver iron concentration is the best method to detect iron overload. 
  4. Mental artery is a branch of facial artery.
A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhea. Histopathology of the duodenum is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

 

  • The image shows histopathology of the duodenum with trophozoites attached to the mucosal surface.
  • These trophozoites have a pear/teardrop shape with 2 nuclei (“face-like” appearance).
  • Classic clinical presentation:
    • Chronic watery diarrhea
    • Steatorrhea (fat malabsorption)
    • Common in immunocompromised patients (eg, HIV)

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Entamoeba histolytica: Causes flask-shaped ulcers in colon and amoebic liver abscess, not chronic watery diarrhea with duodenal pathology.

 

 

Option C. Microsporidia:

 

  • Opportunistic infection in HIV.
  • Shows small intracellular spores within enterocytes, not trophozoites on mucosal surface.

 

 

Option D. Cryptosporidia:

 

  • Acid-fast oocysts seen on stool microscopy.
  • On biopsy, organisms appear as small intracellular but extracytoplasmic forms attached to the brush border.

  2. Syphilis may be transmitted by all the components of blood
  3.  Resolution of a light microscope is 200nm.
  4. Klebsiella species typically exhibit growth on Simmons' citrate agar, and this growth is accompanied by a characteristic blue color change in the medium

choices.text: The primitive streak develops from epiblast
Levator veli palatini arises from 1st pharyngeal arch.
Fabella develops in the lateral head of gastrocnemius
Celiac plexus is located Anterolateral to aorta

questions.text: All of the following are correct except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Levator veli palatini arises from 1st pharyngeal arch.

 

The levator veli palatini is derived from the 4th pharyngeal arch, not the 1st.

 

  • 1st arch muscles include muscles of mastication (masseter, temporalis, pterygoids), mylohyoid, anterior belly of digastric, tensor tympani, and tensor veli palatini (but NOT levator veli palatini).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The primitive streak develops from epiblast: The primitive streak forms on the epiblast during gastrulation and is responsible for the migration of cells that form the mesoderm and endoderm.

 

Option C. Fabella develops in the lateral head of gastrocnemius: The fabella is a sesamoid bone, commonly found in the tendon of the lateral head of the gastrocnemius.

 

Option D. Celiac plexus is located anterolateral to aorta: The celiac plexus (solar plexus) lies around the origin of the celiac trunk, anterolateral to the abdominal aorta near the T12–L1 vertebral level.

questions.text:
Which among the following statements is true regarding the course of the mandibular nerve?

 

  1. Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the temporomandibular joint.
  2. Buccal branch is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the mandibular ramus.
  3. Lingual nerve is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arcs around the submandibular duct.
  4. Ophthalmic nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arises in the middle cranial fossa.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3

 

Mandibular nerve [Cranial Nerve V3]:

 

The mandibular nerve (V3) is the largest branch of the trigeminal nerve, carrying both sensory and motor fibers. It divides into anterior and posterior divisions after entering the infratemporal fossa.

 

Statement 2. Buccal branch is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the mandibular ramus: True. The buccal nerve (sensory, not to be confused with the buccal branch of facial nerve) is from the anterior division. It passes between the two heads of the lateral pterygoid muscle and emerges behind the mandibular ramus to supply the cheek mucosa and skin.

 

Statement 3. Lingual nerve is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arcs around the submandibular duct: True. Lingual nerve is a posterior division branch. It passes anteriorly in the floor of the mouth and loops around the submandibular duct.

 

False Statements:

 

Statement 1. Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the temporomandibular joint: Auriculotemporal nerve is a posterior division branch of V3, not anterior.

 

Statement 4. Ophthalmic nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arises in the middle cranial fossa: Ophthalmic nerve (V1) is a separate division of the trigeminal nerve, not a branch of V3.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
Which of the following media can be used for culturing the organism shown in the image below?
